title: Nichols algebra
summary: In algebra, the Nichols algebra of a braided vector space (with the braiding often induced by a finite group) is a braided Hopf algebra which is denoted by B ( V ) {\displaystyle {\mathfrak {B}}(V)} and named after the mathematician Warren Nichols. It takes the role of quantum Borel part of a pointed Hopf algebra[1] such as a quantum groups and their well known finite-dimensional truncations. Nichols algebras can immediately be used to write down new such quantum groups by using the Radford biproduct.[1]
